title: General Psychology
requirements:
Not for students who have obtained the following grade in Psychology: IB - 5 or above (HL)/GCE-AL - C or above (AL)/Cambridge Pre-U - P2 or above (Principal course)/HKALE - C or above (AL)/AP Exam - 3 or above. 
Not for students who have taken UGED2581.
description: A broad-based introduction to the study of behaviour and mental processes. This course is suitable for students who might be interested in taking further courses in psychology. Topics include learning, development, psychotherapy, the brain and states of consciousness, sensation and perception, memory, social behaviour, personality, psychological disorders, coping and health, stress, and others.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, you will be expected to  I. Demonstrate a basic understanding in various areas of psychology (matches with Learning Goal I) II. Relate and apply major psychological concepts and theories in analyzing real-life situations (matches with Learning Goal I, II, III) III. Conceptualize, structure, and express personal views, both in written and verbal formats, on various topics of psychology  (matches with Learning Goal I, II, III, IV) IV. Develop insights about human behavior and mental processes (matches with Learning Goal I, II, III, IV)
syllabus: Course content 1. Introduction 2. Research Methods  3. Sensation & Perception 4. Memory 5. Brain & Behavior 6. Development 7. Learning 8. Intelligence 9. Motivation & Emotion 10. Personality 11. Social Psychology 12. Psychological Disorders 13. Stress & Health
required_readings: Gazzaniga, M. S., Heatherton., T. F., & Halpern, D. F. (2010). Psychological Science. Norton.

title: Positive Psychology in Everyday Life
requirements: Not for students who have taken UGED1553 and UGED1554.
description: (UGED1554 is double-coded with PSYC1020.) Positive psychology is the scientific study of positive influences in life, namely, positive subjective experiences, positive individual traits, and positive institutions that enhance our quality of life and avert pathologies in time of adversities. This is a knowledge-based course introducing the basic concepts of positive psychology and its application in daily life. This course aims at inspiring students’ interest and self-reflection in positive psychology, as well as the healthy mindsets and lifestyles that it espouses, while encouraging students to plan and initiate habit changes via the integration of positive psychology in their daily lives.
outcome: By the end of this course, students should be able to:  Understand the scientific foundation of positive psychology   Recognize the empirically validated practices that enhance individual well-being   Obtain knowledge about the real life applications of positive psychology in different settings, e.g., educational and business organizations   Reflect on personal experiences using positive psychological concepts  Plan self-improvement habit changes via integration of positive psychology in their daily lives

title: Psychology of Personal Growth
requirements: Not for students who have taken UGED2591, UGED1600/SOWK1150 or SOWK1113.
description: This course aims at providing knowledge about adjustment and personal growth to enable students to develop more effective coping skills and social behaviours. Topics include models of personality, life cycle, self-identity, love and attraction, sexual knowledge and fulfilment, marriage and family, life style and health, stress management, social skills training, assertiveness training and theories on competent personhood.

title: Perspectives in Human Sexuality
requirements:
1. Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
2. Not for students who have taken UGEC2913.
description: This course will explore current theory and research in human sexuality from a variety of perspectives in relation to one's gender, age, sexual orientation, ethnicity and other cultural backgrounds. Students will have the opportunities to critically discuss and analyse issues related to the psychological, sociocultural, and biological aspects of human sexuality, the development of sexual attitudes, values and identity across the lifespan, sexual variations and dysfunctions, sexual coercion, and diversity of sexual behaviours and lifestyles.

title: Consciousness
description: This course addresses topics related to consciousness, arguably the most important yet mysterious aspect of human existence. Topics to be discussed include the variation of the level of consciousness in the waking state, sleep and dreaming, hypnosis, meditation, attention, illusions, extra-sensory perception (ESP), brain decoding and mind reading, machine consciousness, etc. Emphases will be put on the research findings from psychology and neuroscience, theoretical implications, and social applications involved.

title: Your Journey into Psychology
requirements: Not for students who have taken PSYC1090.
description: This course offers an orientation to help beginning students of psychology to appreciate the impact of studying psychology. Students and the teacher will explore and reflect on issues including how psychology relates to oneself, how psychologists think, and how psychology contributes to the society.
outcome: 1. Reflecting on how the study of psychology relates to personal life and world issues 2. Appreciating the perspectives and tools of a psychologist 3. Exploring the various paths followed by students of psychology.
syllabus: The uniqueness of psychology compared with other disciplines The importance of theory and evidence for psychologists Relationship between psychology and personal issues Awareness, empathy, group pressure, and the study of others and yourself Career in professional and non-professional psychology areas. Foreseeing oneself in 5 years; alternative paths of development The role of psychology in promoting human welfare.
required_readings: Resources will be assigned by the corresponding speakers when appropriate.
recommended_readings: Resources will be assigned by the corresponding speakers when appropriate.

title: How Psychologists See Culture
requirements: Not for students who have taken PSYC3610.
description: For humans, culture is like water for fish. We could not gain a good understanding of human behaviors without understanding culture. Taking this perspective, this course explores the ways in which culture shapes mind. The course incorporates a variety of perspectives to analyze the relationship between culture and mind—to gain insight into our own culture, human culture will be compared with animal culture and Chinese culture with non-Chinese cultures. These issues are examined in analyzing a range of psychological phenomena, from the ways in which we understand the world, understand ourselves, and relate to others around us.

title: Communication for Healthy Relationship
description: The course deals with both conceptual and practical issues in interpersonal communication. Both verbal and non-verbal communication modes will be discussed in two major domains: interpersonal relationships, including friendships, romantic relationships, and family communication patterns; as well as in the workplace, focusing on effective negotiation, management, and presentation skills. In each of these domains, students will be exposed to research on how communication modes vary as a function of factors such as gender, culture, and social status, as well as learning how to examine their own and others' communication styles.

title: Introduction to Statistics
requirements: Not for students who have taken COMM3110, DSME2011, ECON2121, GRMD2102, LING3403, PHPC2015, SEEM2430, SOCI2004, SPED2600, STAT2101, 2102, 2001 or 2006.
description: Introduction to statistics as a method in describing and making inferences about numerical data. Emphasis on applications in daily life and psychological research.
outcome: 1. Students will know the procedure to carry out statistical methods in psychology and be able to both use them in practical question and understand them in the scientific literature.  2. Students will understand the logic behind those procedures and know how to solve similar questions.
syllabus: 1. Basic concepts in statistics  2. Descriptive statistics  3. Normal Distribution  4. Hypothesis Testing I  5. Hypothesis Testing II  6. Effect size, Power  7. One-sample, Paired t-test  8. Two-sample t-test  9. One-way ANOVA  10. Correlation  11. Simple Regression  12. Chi-square test  13. Review Session
required_readings: Aron, A., Aron, E. N., & Coups, E. J. (2008). Statistics for Psychology (5th ed.). Upper Saddle River, NJ: Pearson Education.
recommended_readings: Green, S. B., & Salkind, N. J. (2008). Using SPSS for Windows and Macintosh: Analyzing and Understanding Data. Upper Saddle River, NJ: Pearson Education.

title: Experimental Design
description: Introduction to the various strategies and techniques of experimental research and data analysis employed in psychology. Participation in laboratories or independent research required.
outcome: 1. Students will know the basic types of experimental designs (e.g., within-subjects designs vs. between-subjects designs) and know how to use them appropriately in various situations. 2. Students will know how to address the important issues in designing and conducting psychological experiments (e.g., research ethics, literature review, control groups, presentations).
syllabus: 1. Scientific thinking in Psychology 2. Developing research ideas 3. Experimental approaches 4. Control problem 1 5 Control problem 2 6. Experimental design 1 7. Experimental design 2 8. Other research methods 9. Measurements and data analysis 10. Scientific practice
required_readings: Research In Psychology: Methods and Design (6/E) by C. James Goodwin

title: Psychological Testing
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC2010 or any of its equivalent courses (COMM3110, DSME2010 & 2020, ECON2121, GRMD2102, SEEM2430, SOCI1004, SPED2600, STAT2101 & 2102, or STAT2001 & 2006).
description: Basic principles of psychological measurement. Scaling models based on psychophysical and psychological methods, including constant methods, pair-comparisons, rank order, interval and ratio judgements. Issues in internal structure of measures such as variance and covariance, measurement error, and validity and reliability.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, you will have a better understanding about the basic concepts and principles of psychological testing. In particular, you will know how to evaluate the quality of a psychological test scientifically.
syllabus: Basic Concepts in Psychological Measurement Scales, Transformations, and Norms Scale Construction Test Development Online Resources for Questionnaire Construction Theory of Summated Scores Reliability Validity Factor Analysis Item Analysis
required_readings: Cohen, R.J., & Swerdlik, M.E. (2010). Psychological Testing and Assessment: An Introduction to Test and Measurement (7th ed). New York, NY: McGraw Hill.

title: Qualitative Research Methods
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
description: This course introduces students to the methods of doing qualitative research in psychology. We will begin by discussing qualitative research as a general research strategy and work through several interrelated methods of collecting qualitative data: unstructured observations, structured observations, interviews (again, varying in range from completely open-ended to more directed), diaries, and public expressions. In addition, we will discuss how to design are search project that involves qualitative methods, as well as several methods for collecting, analysing, interpreting, and writing up reports based on qualitative data. Students will be given hands-on exercises in collecting interview and observational data and will be expected to transcribe audio and/or video-recordings that they make and take field notes of their experiences.

title: Physiological Psychology
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGED2581.
description: The biological bases of behaviour, including central nervous system, peripheral nervous system, and the internal chemical environment. The relationship between such psychological processes as motivation, states of consciousness, memory, emotions,and learning and underlying physiological and neurophysiological events.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students are expected to achieve:  1. Understand major concepts and research findings in each major aspects of physiological psychology, and integrate knowledge for the human nervous system to form an overall impression of how it functions as unified system.  2. Be able to comprehend and assess recent research progress in selected research areas in brain sciences.
syllabus: 1. Introduction 2. Neuron and synapse 3. Neural anatomy 4. Research methods 5. Vision 6. Other senses 7. Movement 8. Sleep 9. Emotion 10. Learning and memory 11. Language 12. Disorders
required_readings: Neil R. Carlson. Physiology of behavior Allyn & Bacon.
recommended_readings: Laura A. Freberg. Discovering Biological Psychology, Houghton Mifflin Company

title: Sensation and Perception
requirements: Prerequisite: (PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581) and PSYC2010 or its equivalent courses (COMM3110, DSME2010 & 2020, ECON2121, GRMD2102, SEEM2430, SOCI1004, SPED2600, STAT2101 & 2102 or STAT2001 & 2006).
description: This course covers fundamental concepts and principles of sensory and perceptual processes, with an emphasis on psychophysical and scaling methods and experimental techniques. Contents include: psychophysics and scaling, sensory systems, perceptual development, constancies and illusions, and attention.
outcome: 1. Understanding the processes of creating perception from sensory stimuli, focusing on an approach of information processing.  2. Understanding perception from a few aspects, what is its functional goal, How is it implemented, what are the important sub-systems and how do they behave.
syllabus: 1 Introduction 2 Physiology of Vision 3 Spatial Vision 4 Object and Structure 5 Attention 6 Color 7 Depth  8 Motion 9 High-level vision 10 Perception of other groups 11 Perception of other modalities 12 Current directions in visual perception 13 Review session
required_readings: Goldstein, E. B.. Sensation and Perception. Pacific Grove, CA: Wadsworth.
recommended_readings: Rock, I. Perception. Scientific American Library/W. H. Freeman.

title: Basic Learning Processes
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
description: Methods and findings in the study of learning with emphasis on their relation to theories of learning. Special consideration given to the way in which learning theory may be applied to human behaviour. Some laboratory participation required.
outcome: The above three learning goals focusing on understanding, critical thinking, and application translate specifically to the following concrete learning outcomes: 1. Students are able to explain to others what learning, memory, and behaviorism are. 2. Students are able to discuss some basic principles governing learning and memory behavior in an informative fashion. 3. Students are able to develop sensible arguments that are based upon these principles and apply them effectively to daily life observations. 4. Students can apply these principles to some other areas of psychology and even other branches of social science. 5. Students can analyze and discuss educational issues in an informative fashion.
syllabus: 1. instinctive behaviour and simple learning 2. classical conditioning I 3. classical conditioning II 4. instrumental conditioning I 5. instrumental conditioning II 6. theories I 7. theories II 8. theories III 9. control of behaviour I  10. control of behaviour II 11. control of behaviour III 12. verbal learning I 13. verbal learning II
required_readings: Domjan, M. The Principles of Learning and Behavior. CA: Wadsworth.
recommended_readings: Chapters 12 and 13 from Klein, S. B.. Learning: Principles and Applications. NY: McGraw-Hill.

title: Memory and Cognition
requirements:
1. Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
2. Not for students who have taken UGEB2721 or LING2201.
description: This course introduces basic concepts, theories, methods, findings, and new developments in the cognitive study of human memory. Topics to be covered include sensory memory, attention, pattern recognition, memory and forgetting, picture memory, and mental imagery.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, you should be able to:  1) Understand the major concepts, findings, and theories in cognitive psychology  2) Be able to understand and compare cognitive theories on different topics  3) Obtain skills and experience in conducting research in cognitive psychology  4) Develop critical thinking skills to evaluate empirical evidence  5) Practice on effective communication through written and oral presentation  6) Apply the knowledge about cognition to enhance performance in daily life  7) Appreciate the values of cognitive psychology
syllabus: 1. Introduction  2. Approaches to the cognitive study of human mind  3. Mental chronometry  4. Perceptual processes 5. Attention  6. Memory and forgetting  7. Memory and processing of nonverbal information  8. Mental imagery  9. Levels of processing  10. Explicit and implicit memory Memory  11. Higher mental processes

title: Developmental Psychology
requirements:
Pre-requisite:PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
Not for students who have taken PSYC2530 or PSYC3540 or SOWK2110 or EDUC2310.
description: The goal of this course is to introduce students to the field of developmental psychology. We will explore theories, research methods, and research findings concerning physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development from infancy to old age. We will pay particular attention to the role of culture in shaping lifespan development.
outcome: 1. Obtain a knowledge base of developmental psychology 2. Apply major concepts, theories, and research findings in developmental psychology to analyze real-life issues 3. Understand typical research methods in developmental psychology and practice using them
syllabus: 1. Recurrent themes and representative theories in developmental psychology 2. Typical research methods in developmental psychology 3. Classical work on cognitive development and contemporary trends 4. Classical work on moral development and contemporary trends 5. Temperament and attachment 6. Self-development and gender development 7. Achievement motivation 8. Contexts for development I: The family 9. Contexts for development II: Peers, school, neighborhood, and the media 10. Adolescence and emerging adulthood 11. Love and work during adulthood 12. Health and wellness during adulthood, aging 13. Dying, death, and grieving
required_readings: textbook and/or articles

title: Social Psychology
requirements: Prerepuisite: PSYC1000 or PSYC1620 or PSYC1630 or UGED2581.
description: Major concepts and methods used in studying the individual's behaviour in social settings. Interpersonal attraction, leadership, aggression, group processes, attitude change and person perception.
outcome: Understand concepts and theories in social psychology. Understand how research in social psychology is conducted.  Apply social psychology to everyday life.  Effectively communicate issues relevant to social psychology.  Develop insight into your own and others’ social behaviors.
syllabus: Introduction Groups Attraction Relationships Social Self Social Influence Persuasion Attitudes, Behavior, and Rationalization Understanding Others Social Judgment Stereotyping, Prejudice, Discrimination Helping, Hurting, and Cooperating  Emotion
required_readings: Gilovich, T., Keltner, D. & Nisbett, R.E. Social Psychology. New York:W.W. Norton

title: Personality Psychology
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
description: This course presents the major theoretical approaches to personality and the basic techniques utilized to assess personality differences. The focus is on everyday life applications, empirical evidence in support and against the theories, and the design, application, and interpretation of personality questionnaires.
outcome: 1: familiarize with the key classical and contemporary experimental studies and findings in personality psychology 2: understand, relate and apply the key personality psychological concepts to daily life 3: conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during tutorial discussions, on personality psychology related topics 4: design, direct and regulate own study plan on personality psychology, from identifying the problem, setting learning objectives, researching on relevant information, reflecting on what has been learnt, to applying the knowledge to future problems
syllabus: Course Syllabus 1. What is personality? 2. How do we go about studying personality? 3. How do we describe personality? Types, traits & interactionism 4. Biological Processes I 5. Biological Processes II 6. Psychodynamic perspective I 7. Psychodynamic perspective II 8. Neoanalytic perspective  9. Learning perspective 10. Phenomenological perspective I 11. Phenomenological perspective II 12. Cognitive self-regulation perspective I 13. Cognitive self-regulation perspective II
required_readings: Carver, C. S. & Scheier, M. F. Perspectives on Personality (6th edition) Boston: Allyn & Bacon.

title: Neuropsychology
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581.
description: This course provides basic introduction of human brain functions and the abnormal cognitive functions associated with brain damage. It focuses on exploring the relationship between the human brain and behaviours. It also examines the neural bases and clinical presentation of various types of cognitive disorders, such as dyslexia, amnesia, disorders of attention and emotion processing.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students are expected to: 1. Acquire fundamental understanding of some basic but important concepts and theories in neuropsychology.  2. Learn about the value and application of neuropsychological concepts.
syllabus: Week/Topic and Aims (in bullets point) 1. Introduction: Philosophy Behind Neuropsychology • to allow students to have general idea about neuropsychology and relationships between brain and behavior  • to introduce the value of neuropsychology in understanding human behavior 2. Basic Neuroanatomy • to introduce basic but important knowledge in major concepts about neuroanatomy, e.g., various brain regions and their associated functions, mechanism of neuronal activity 3. Methods in Neuropsychology & Hemispheric Specialization  • to introduce various methods in studying the brain functions, e.g., brain imaging techniques and study of brain-damaged patients • to introduce the fundamental concept of hemispheric specialization and its significance in understanding our brain functions  4. Dementia • to introduce the definition of dementia and its various subtypes and etiologies • to briefly introduce the cognitive deficits associated with different types of dementia  5. Memory  • to introduce various memory models in understanding memory  • to briefly introduce possible etiologies and characteristics of various types of memory disorders  6. Language • to introduce the fundamental concept of language  • to briefly illustrate the characteristics of various types of language impairment  7. Mid-Term Examination • to be tested on the basic knowledge in neuropsychology and neuroanatomy and important concepts of brain functions, including memory and language, and the associated deficits 8. Executive Function  • to define executive functions and the associated cognitive abilities  • to briefly illustrate the characteristics of various types of executive dysfunctions  9. Object Recognition & Spatial Processing • to briefly introduce the concept of object recognition and spatial processing • to briefly illustrate the characteristics of various forms of impairment in object recognition and spatial processing 10. Motor Control  • to introduce the fundamental concept of motor control • to briefly illustrate the characteristics of various types of motor control problems 11. Emotion  • to introduce the fundamental concept of emotion processing • to briefly illustrate the characteristics of various types of emotion disorders and its relation to the brain 12. Traumatic Brain Injury  • to define traumatic brain injury • to briefly introduce possible cognitive deficits associated with traumatic brain injury 13. Learning and Neuropsychiatric Disorders of Childhood  • to briefly introduce various types of learning and neuropsychiatric disorders of childhood
required_readings: Martin, G. N. (2006). Human Neuropsychology (2nd Ed). Hertfordshire, UK: Prentice Hall Europe.

title: Human Intelligence
requirements:
1. Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
2. Not for students who have taken UGEB2721.
description: This course introduces major theories, issues, methods, findings, and new developments in human intelligence from the perspective of cognitive psychology. Topics to be covered include representations and structures of knowledge, complex cognitive skills (e.g., language and thought, discourse comprehension, and problem-solving) and related mental operations, as well as cross-cultural studies of cognition.

title: Psychology and Law
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581.
description: This course provides a general introduction to the interdisciplinary field of psychology and law. Topics covered include criminality, criminal profiling, mental competence, malingering, eyewitness testimony, lie detection, jury decision-making and risk and needs assessment in correctional psychology. Implications of research findings will be discussed to evaluate the practicality of the constructs, and emphasis will be given to the relevance of psychological concepts to the different legal systems around the world.

title: Psychology of Language
requirements:
1. Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
2. Not for students who have taken ENGE3610 or LING3202.
description: This course brings together the theoretical and empirical tools of psychology and linguistics to study the mental processes underlying the acquisition and use of language, with special emphasis on the topics of grammar and psychology, psycholinguistic investigations of grammar, language development in the child, problems of meaning, and language and cognition.
outcome: 1. Students are able to explain to others what language, language learning,  bilingualism, syntax, semantics, phonology, and speech are 2. Students are able to discuss some basic principles governing language learning and processing in an informative fashion  3. Students are able to develop sensible arguments that are based upon these principles and apply them effectively to daily life observations 4. Students can analyze and discuss issues surrounding language education in an informative fashion

title: Psychology of Music
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581.
description: The purpose of this course is to discuss and explore the psychological mechanisms involved in the perception, development, performance, and interpretation of music. These topics are approached via neurological, cognitive, developmental, and socio-cultural methods. Some of the topics include the perception of pitch and rhythm, musical structure, practice and the development of musical expertise, and the social dynamics in an ensemble. It is hoped that after taking this course students are able to analyze and discuss a range of musical phenomena and activities from a psychological point of view.

title: Problem Solving and Creativity
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
description: This course is to introduce cognitive and social approaches to problem-solving and creativity. This includes ways in which creativity, intelligence, E.Q., and interpersonal sensitivity affect the kinds of problems to be solved and the manner in which they are solved. Social and cultural contexts of problem solving and creativity will be explored. The role of problem solving and creativity for turning ideas into action (entrepreneurship) will also be discussed.

title: Machine Learning in Psychology
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581.
description: This course is designed to provide students with a foundational understanding of machine learning concepts and techniques, and their applications in psychology. Throughout the course, students will gain hands-on experience with various algorithms, such as supervised and unsupervised learning, techniques for feature selection, model evaluation, and the use of advanced methods such as neural networks and large language models. The course is designed to enable students to apply machine learning tools to psychological research, thereby fostering skills in data-driven hypothesis testing and research innovation.

title: Computational Modeling in Psychology
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581.
description: This course provides an overview of the principles and practices of computational modeling. Students will learn to use computational models to understand cognitive functions (e.g., memory, language, cognitive control) arise from computations in the brain and study social interactions and group behaviors. Topics will include the purpose of models, distinguishing good modeling from bad, implementing a model, fitting a model to data, evaluating the fit of a model, comparing competing models, investigating special cases of a model, and developing and testing new models. Additionally, the course will introduce students to the latest modeling approaches that have been employed to understand human behaviors, including neural networks and large language models.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, you will be able to: Comprehend the basic principles of computational modeling and its roles in psychological research. Develop basic computational models to simulate psychological phenomena and evaluate its performance. Integrate computational models with empirical data from psychological experiments. Communicate the concepts and results of computational models to a non-specialist audience.
syllabus: Key principles and concepts in computational modeling Purposes and steps in developing computational models Fitting models with empirical data Model evaluation, comparison, and selection Use of computational models in cognitive processes: brain functions Use of computational models in cognitive processes: memory Modeling social interactions and group behaviors Use of large language models in psychology Applications of computational models to understand real-life problems Communication for results of computational modeling Current trends and future directions of computational modeling
required_readings: Marr, D. (2010). Vision: A computational investigation into the human representation and processing of visual information. London, England: The MIT Press.Farrell, S., & Lewandowsky, S. (2018). Computational modeling of cognition and behavior. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.
recommended_readings: Anderson, J.R. (1996). The architecture of cognition (1st ed.). Cambridge: Psychology Press. Minsky, M. (1988). Society of mind. New York: Simon and Schuster, Inc.

title: Educational Psychology
requirements:
Pre-requisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
Not for students who have taken EDUC3311.
description: This course introduces the application of theoretical principles and research findings from the field of psychology to educational settings. Topics to be covered include general instructional issues, learning and motivation, effective instruction, educating students with special needs, measurement and evaluation. Special emphasis is placed on the understanding and solution of educational problems in the local community.

title: Culture and Psychology
requirements:
Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581.
Not for students who have taken PSYC1620.
description: People born in different cultures experience different physical and social environments. These factors combine with unique historical heritages to shape mind. This course exposes students to accumulated knowledge on the interactive relationships between culture and mind. Special attention will be given to China and Asia-Pacific.
outcome: - Learn theories and concepts of cross-cultural psychology. - Develop a comprehensive understanding of how culture influences mental processes. - Critically examine Chinese culture: its distinctive features and similarities with other cultures.  - Become aware of psychological issues surrounding cross-cultural exchanges, diversity, and globalization.
syllabus: 1.  Introduction. How are individuals similar to and different from others? Who are Chinese? What is Chinese culture?  2. What Is Culture? How does culture get in our head? Do animals have cultures? What is cultural learning? 3. Cultural Change. How do cultures emerge and change? What are the processes of cultural change? Are cultures converging? 4. Acculturation. What happens when people move to a new culture? What happens when people have more than one culture? 5. Development. What is the sensitive period of culture? Differences in childhood experience across cultures. 6. Self and Personality. Culture and personality. Independent self vs. interdependent self. 7. Motivation. “Standing out” versus “fitting in.” Culture and self-evaluation.  8. Control and Choice. Influencing others and adjusting to the environment. Paradox of choice.  9. Thinking. Cultural differences in habits of thoughts: differences in attention, perception, attribution, and reasoning.  10. Language and Communication. Language and thought. High and low context culture. Sapir-Whorf hypothesis.  11. Emotions. Does emotion expression vary across cultures? Cultural variation in ideal affect. Happiness.  12. Groups and Social Relationships. Base of interpersonal attraction. Friendship. Inter-group relationships.  13. Mental and Physical health. Culture bound syndromes. Culture and physical health.
required_readings: Heine, S. J. (2008). Cultural psychology. New York: Norton.

title: Culture, Groups and Social Behaviour
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC2620.
description: This is an introductory course on social dilemmas. Social dilemma is a mixed-motive situation in which a person’s selfish interest to maximize his or her own gain may undermine the collective interest of everyone. The basic research question is “why do people cooperate?” Social dilemma is a theoretical model describing the general conflict between cooperation and competition in all sorts of real-life situations, e.g., conserving energy, donating blood, contributing to charities, or using public transportation. The course introduces different types of social dilemmas like prisoner’s dilemma, public goods, and resource dilemmas. Emphasizing a social psychological perspective, we will also cover psychological factors like leadership, trust, criticality, and social value orientation that have been found to affect cooperation in social dilemmas. Theories and concepts will be illustrated through various social dilemma games in tutorials.

title: Psychology of Gender
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
description: Gender affects people’s experiences, judgments and beliefs. This course reviews various perspectives on the psychology of gender. An analytical approach to understanding socialization, policies and cultures from a gendered perspective will be explored. Consequences of gender bias will be discussed. Upon completion of the course, students should demonstrate basic understanding of the major conceptual models of gender psychology and have better awareness of gender issues in different social and cultural contexts.

title: Emotion and Motivation
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
description: This course discusses the theories and empirical findings on emotions and other related topics (such as subjective experience, happiness, life satisfaction and emotion states). Students will learn how emotions influence the ways we think and behave, the situations we seek, and the ways we make sense of our lives.

title: Abnormal Psychology
requirements:
Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
Not for students who have taken SOWK2140.
description: Various types of psychological disorders falling under psychiatric nomenclature and other behavioural models. Theories and research concerning the origin, diagnosis and treatment of these disorders.
outcome: 1. Learn the basic concepts of abnormal psychology. 2. Learn how brain predispositions and upbringing experience interact to lead to mental disorders. 3. Learn to do detailed clinical case analysis according to the integrative perspective. 4. Develop insights into your own and others’ mental processes. 5. Learn to use E-journals and internet in pursuing personal interests in this field.
syllabus: 1. Brain plasticity, experience, and mental disorders 2. Stress and mental disorders 3. Diagnosing mental disorders 4. Anxiety disorders 5. Mood disorders 6. Somatoform and dissociative disorders 7. Substance-related disorders 8. Gender identity and sex-related disorders   9. Eating Disorders 10. Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders 11. Personality disorders 12. ADHD, autism and mental retardation
required_readings: Butcher, J.N., Mineka, S., & Hooley, J.M. (2011). Abnormal Psychology: Core Concepts (2nd Ed.). Boston: Pearson.
recommended_readings: There will be other assigned readings for different lectures and tutorials. Students will be taught to download most of these readings from E-journal.

title: Health Psychology
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
description: This course provides an overview of health psychology and the role of health psychologists in clinical and research settings. It examines biological, psychological, and social factors in the conceptions of health and health related attitudes, beliefs and behaviors. Topics include health promotion, behavioral health and illness prevention, substance abuse, stress and coping, management of chronic and terminal illness, pain management, and health services. Students will gain an understanding of the theory and everyday life applications of health psychology in contemporary societies.

title: Professional Issues and Development in Mental Health Practice
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000
description: Issues of professional ethics, interdisciplinary approach and teamwork, professional development, and personal growth will be discussed with students as fundamentals in providing care to clients. A scientifically based psychosocial framework in conceptualizing and understanding individuals’ multi-faceted needs (physical and mental health, social and occupational needs) along with considerations of policy and structural issues to support individuals’ recovery will be discussed. Issues around diversity and mental health disparities are discussed to raise the consciousness of students.
outcome: 1. Be familiar with the key concepts in mental health practice 2. Be able to weigh various perspectives underlying an ethical dilemma 3. Be aware of cultural diversity in mental health related issues 4. Be able to conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during in-class discussions, on mental health practice and related topics
syllabus: • Professional conduct and ethics • Development as a mental health provider • Models of mental health, recovery, and related practice • Policies related to mental health service delivery • Diversity and cultural competence

title: Evidence-based Mental Health Practice
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581
description: This course will introduce the essence of evidence-based practice and stepped care model in the delivery of mental health services. Students will understand how evidence is built around a certain intervention approach and/or for specific mental disorders. The issue of evidence will be discussed from multiple perspectives, from various quantitative approaches to establish efficacy and effectiveness to qualitative accounts from various stakeholders, including individuals with lived experience of mental health issues. Issues on the implementation and dissemination of evidence-based practice in real life settings will be discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, you will be able to a. Describe the basics of evidence-based practice and stepped care model in the delivery of mental health services b. Describe the phenomena, cognitive-behavioral models, and interventions of common mental health problems c. Demonstrate competence in quantitatively and qualitatively evaluating a treatment or intervention program.

title: Counseling Theories and their Applications to Clinical, Career and Organizational Settings
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581
description: This course will examine some common counseling theories and their usefulness in and applications in, various domains (clinical interventions, career counseling at schools, talent development by human resources). Coaching and some organizational development applications will be discussed and external speakers will provide an applied perspective on the field.

title: Engagement and Assessment of Individuals with Common Mental Health Problems
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC3730 & PSYC3740
description: To effectively engage and assess individuals with common mental health difficulties, students will gain an understanding and competency in the application of “common factors” (e.g., active listening, rapport building, expression of empathy), knowledge in common mental health problems, and evidence-based interventions. The focus will be on training students on effective communication skills and assessment of individuals with anxiety and depression. Students will be trained on core skills of engagement, communication, and assessment through skills-based practices and role-plays. Students are expected to engage in self-practice self-reflection throughout the course by themselves or with their classmates. In order to qualify for practicum in guided self-help, students must pass the minimal competency requirements in conducting a complete assessment.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, you will be able to a. Describe the background knowledge pertinent to the three sections of an assessment including information gathering, information giving, and shared decision making. b. Acquire micro skills to engage a client and develop a therapeutic alliance. c. Demonstrate competence in conducting a collaborative assessment for the low-intensity psychological treatment program for common mental health problems. d. Demonstrate competence in delivering an assessment using a range of methods including face-to-face, telephone, and electronic communication. e. Reflect upon the process and outcome of clinical work in relation to theory and research evidence.
syllabus: Evidence-based assessment and strategies a. Information gathering - The nature of chief complains and their impacts - Risk assessment - Outcome measures - Past treatment experience, current treatments plan, and expectation b. Information giving - Problem statement - Functional analysis with the ABC model c. Shared decision making - Treatment option and plan - Homework assignment

title: Evidence Based Low Intensity Interventions for Common Mental Health Problems
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC3760
description: Based on the evidence-based approaches for treatment of individuals with mild to moderate levels of common mental health problems, students will gain competency on a range of these evidence-based interventions, particularly low intensity cognitive behavioral interventions. Emphasis is put on clinical skills building to develop students’ “specific factors” competencies in the provision of low-intensity cognitive behavioral interventions using the guided self-help approach. Students will be trained on core skills of guided self-help through skills-based practices and role-plays. Students are expected to engage in self-practice self-reflection throughout the course by themselves or with their classmates. In order to qualify for practicum in guided self-help, students must pass the minimal competency requirements in conducting a complete intervention using the guided self-help approach.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, you will be able to a. Demonstrate competence in planning a collaborative low-intensity psychological treatment programme for common mental health problems b. Describe a range of evidence-based interventions and strategies to assist patients to manage their emotional distress and disturbance c. Evaluate and use competently low-intensity basic, intervention-specific and problem-specific techniques such as behavioural activation, exposure, guided problem solving, and dealing with worry, according to individualised assessment and theoretical basis d. Demonstrate competence in delivering low-intensity interventions using a range of methods including face-to-face, telephone and electronic communication e. Evaluate the role of case management and stepped-care approaches to managing common mental health problems in primary care, including ongoing risk management appropriate to service protocols f. Reflect upon the processes and outcome of clinical work in relation to theory and research evidence

title: Applied Psychology in Business
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
description: The course covers the application of psychological knowledge in service and industrial operations. Topics include the psychological foundation of consumer behaviour and advertising, the psychological analysis of the interaction between sales personnel and customers, economic psychology, current motivational techniques for enhancing performance, team-building, the psychology of industrial relations, and other current topics. The course will give equal emphasis to theories and applications.

title: Industrial-Organizational Psychology
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
description: This course is an introduction to the applications of principles and theories in psychology to the workplace. Topics include job analysis, recruitment and selection, training and development, performance appraisal, motivation, job satisfaction, work stress, group dynamics, leadership and organizational development.
outcome: 1. Be knowledgeable of the topics, methodologies, essential concepts and findings in Industrial-Organizational Psychology 2. Be able to reflect upon work related issues from a psychological perspective 3. Be able to recognize the values in industrial-organizational psychology
syllabus: 1. Introduction 2. Job analysis  3. Employee Selection & equal opportunity 4. Performance Appraisal 5. Training and Development 6. Motivation 7. Job Attitudes 8. Stress and Workers Well-being  9. Group Processes and Work Teams 10. Leadership
required_readings: Riggio, E. R. (2008). Introduction to Industrial/Organizational Psychology (5th ed.). Upper Saddle River, N.J.: Pearson
recommended_readings: There will be journal articles, book chapters, or online articles to be assigned for the different tutorials.

title: Psychology in Action I
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581
description: This course helps students to apply psychology to tackle social issues. Students will learn about successful stories of psychology applications, and under the guidance of the teaching team, design and implement their own projects in an attempt to apply theories and findings of psychology to make an impact on people's lives and the society-at-large.A problem-based learning approach will be implemented in this course. Under the framework of design thinking, students will identify the issue of interest and apply their psychological knowledge to create changes on the issues. Students will be engaged in a wide range of in-class discussions, problem-based activities, and self-reflection processes to facilitate their learning. Students are expected to go outside the classroom, connect with the potential stakeholders and discuss their proposal with them. By the end of the course, students are required to give a group presentation and submit a project proposal to consolidate their thinking and efforts and to reflect on the possibility of future actions.Advisory: For Psychology Majors only.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be expected to: 1. appreciate the impacts of the existing cases of psychology applications; 2. broaden and deepen their understanding of the rationale and impacts of the existing cases of psychology applications; 3. understand, relate, and apply the psychological concepts to create changes on some problems in the real life; 4. emerge from the course with innovative and realistic ideas to implement their knowledge, skills, and values in psychology in applied settings;  5. understand and reflect on the ethical issues involved in applied work; AND 6. conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas both in written assignments and during weekly discussions.

title: Practicum in Neuroscience and Psychology
description: This course provides students an opportunity to conduct research in a neuroscience laboratory. Students will gain hands-on experience in using neuroscience techniques available to conduct psychological research. Emphases will be placed on experiment programming, data collection, data analyses, results presentation, report writing and reflection papers under the guidance of a faculty member. Upon the completion of this course, students should be able to apply textbook knowledge to actual research, and identify the strengths and limitations of neuroscience techniques in psychological research. The experience would serve as a springboard for students to adopt neuroscience reasoning and techniques in any sub-fields of psychology research.Advisory: For Psychology Major Year 2 & 3 students only.

title: Practicum in Education and Human Development
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGED2581, PSYC2530 or 2540 or 3540 or 3550, and permission of course teacher.
description: This course introduces students to applied developmental settings such as schools, organizations that work with children and adolescents, and medical institutions such that they will have an opportunity to apply the theories and subject matter of developmental and educational psychology in the "real world". Students will arrange a practicum placement together with the course lecturer.Advisory: For Psychology Majors only.
outcome: Students will: 1. Refresh, deepen, and broaden their understanding of concepts, theoretical perspectives, and empirical findings in educational and/or developmental psychology that are relevant to observations made and tasks/projects worked on at the placement site. 2. Apply their understanding of theory and research in psychology in general and educational and/or developmental psychology in particular to personal, organizational, and social issues. 3. Recognize and appreciate socio-cultural complexity and diversity. 4. Develop insights into their own and others’ behavior and psyche and employ effective strategies for self-management and self-improvement. 5. Emerge from the course with realistic ideas about how to implement their knowledge, skills, and values in psychology in a variety of applied settings. 6. Communicate effectively in a variety of formats.
syllabus: The focus of the course is on the practical nature of psychology. Therefore, there will be no formal lectures. Instead, the course will consist of the following activities:  Course Activities:  1. Preparatory meetings: Before starting the practicum, each student will meet with the field supervisor (usually together with the professor). During the meeting, the student should discuss with the field supervisor on their mutual expectations for the practicum, the kind of practical work available at the placement, and preparations that need to be made, etc. The student should also set his/her work schedule with the supervisor.  2. Practicum: Each student is expected to work for approximately 160 hours in total at the placement. A student should be at the placement for 2 full days per week. Each student should decide with the field supervisor as soon as possible a fixed weekly schedule for his/her work at the placement. A copy of the finalized schedule should be submitted to the professor for record. Throughout the semester, each student will receive supervision and advice from the field supervisor as well as the professor and the tutor.  3. Group discussions: There will be approximately biweekly group discussion sessions, each taking around 2.5 hours. Additional sessions may be held throughout the semester for guest speeches or near the end of the semester for oral presentations if needed.  Students are expected to openly share their experience working at different placements (e.g., any observations they make, any practical work they engage in, any difficulties or problems they encounter). It is essential that students learn from one another’s experience and feel free to seek as well as give advice and emotional support in a mutually understanding and helpful environment.
required_readings: None. (note: Students do the practicum of various settings so no one-fill-all textbook for the course. Individual guidance will be given indeed.)

title: Practicum in Social and Industrial-Organizational Psychology
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGED2581, and permission of course teacher.
description: This course introduces students to work settings such as business corporations, banks, governmental and non-governmental organizations in which they will have an opportunity to apply the theories and subject matter of social and industrial/organizational psychology in the "real world". Students will arrange a practicum placement together with the course lecturer.Advisory: For Psychology Major Year 2 & 3 students only.

title: Practicum in Psychology and Health
requirements: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGED2581, PSYC2780 or 3700 or 3720 or 3730 or 3740, and permission of course teacher.
description: This course focuses on training students in the application of theories and practice related to clinical and health psychology across social welfare, health, and other applied settings in the community. Students will be assigned a practicum placement by the course instructor.Advisory: For Psychology Majors only.
outcome: 1. understand, relate, and apply the key psychological concepts in applied settings  2. gain hands-on experience in applied settings 3. conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during weekly discussions, on health/clinical psychology-related topics  4. design, direct, and regulate one’s work plan, from generating original ideas, listing of possible plans, setting expected work outcomes, researching on relevant information, reflecting on what have been learned, to applying the knowledge in future encounter at applied settings
syllabus: 1. Preparatory meeting: Students will contact their practicum supervisors before the beginning of the practicum. The format of this meeting may vary (phone or in-person), depending on the preference of the supervisors and arrangements made with the agencies. requirements: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC3730, 3740, 3760, 3770 and permission of course instructor
description: Students will provide guided self-help services in community settings under the supervision of clinical psychologists. Students at the practicum settings will work as part of the team in providing evidence-based services to individuals with mild to moderate common mental health difficulties. Issues pertinent to service delivery such as risk management, medication, and multi-cultural competence are discussed to raise the awareness, sensitivity, and competence of students in providing services. The science and practice of adaptations during the service implementation to accommodate individuals from diverse social, cultural, health, economic, and occupational backgrounds as well as in-service settings with varied resources and community contexts will be introduced to enhance students’ critical appreciation of the knowledge, attitudes, and competencies required to support clients’ recovery in an inclusive, value-driven way. title: Statistics and Research Design in Psychological Science
requirements: For students in MA Psychology
description: In this course students will learn to understand the logic, purpose and techniques of statistical analyses, particularly those for psychology, and learn the basic types of experimental designs (e.g., within-subjects designs vs. between-subjects designs) and know how to use them appropriately in various situations. Students will also learn to address the important issues in designing and conducting psychological experiments (e.g., Research ethics, Literature review, Control groups, Presentations). We will emphasize the understanding of logic and attempt to reduce load of memory.
outcome: 1. Students will know the procedure to carry out statistical methods in psychology and be able to both use them in practical question and understand them in the scientific literature. 2. Students will understand the logic behind those procedures and know how to solve similar questions. 3. Students will know the basic types of experimental designs (e.g., within-subjects designs vs. between-subjects designs) and know how to use them appropriately in various situations. 4. Students will know how to address the important issues in designing and conducting psychological experiments (e.g., Research ethics, Literature review, Control groups, Presentations).
syllabus: 1. Descriptive statistics 2. Normal Distribution and Hypothesis Testing 3. Z-test, Effect size, Power 4. t-test and ANOVA 5. Correlation, regression, and Chi-square test 6. Scientific thinking in Psychology 7. Developing research ideas 8. Experimental approaches 9. Control problem 10. Experimental design 1 11. Experimental design 2 12. Other research methods 13. Other issues (Ethics, Presentation, etc)

title: Industrial-organizational Psychology
requirements: For students in MA in Psychology programme
description: Work is an indispensable part of life. And the study of psychology at work is a domain of Industrial/ Organizational (I/O) psychology. This course focuses on the application of psychological methods and principles in understanding the world of work and work behaviors.
outcome: 1.  Be knowledgeable of the topics, methodologies, essential concepts and findings in Industrial-organizational Psychology2.  Be able to reflect upon work related issues from a psychological perspective3.  Be able to recognize the values in industrial-organizational psychology
syllabus: 1.    Introduction This is a broad overview of what I/O psychology is and its roots, early history and future development.   2.    Job analysis  This topic introduces the systematic study of a job’s task, the job analysis method and techniques, how job analysis relates to other personnel functions.   3.    Recruitment & Selection This topic decomposes each step in selecting employees in detail. The strengths and weaknesses of the tools used in the selection process are examined. The guidance and regulations with regard to protection against discrimination in employment is discussed.   4.    Performance Appraisal This lecture begins with the purposes of performance appraisals, then describes methods of various performance rating methods and discusses their advantages and disadvantages. Components of a successful training program model will be identified.    6.    Motivation This topic examines various theories of job motivation and their applications. The relationship between motivation and work performance will be illustrated.   7.    Positive & Negative Employee Attitudes This topic is about the relationship between job satisfaction and organizational commitment and between employees’ job attitudes and work behaviors. Factors that can increase positive attitudes and behaviors will be illustrated. This topic also looks at different sources, measurement, effects, and coping strategies of worker stress.   8.    Group Processes and Work Teams This lecture introduces central concepts of group dynamics at work settings including organizational socialization, group conformity, group cohesiveness, group conflicts, groupthink, and group polarization. The definition of work teams and the factors in leading effective work teams will be discussed.   9.    Leadership This topic covers different theories of leadership and discusses their merits and demerits in depth. Applications of theories will be illustrated.

title: Cognitive Psychology
requirements: For students in MA Psychology
description: This course aims at inspiring students to consider the question of how human being can dominate the earth from the perspective of cognitive psychology. Throughout the evolutionary history, our ancestors developed a repertoire of cognitive skills that are fundamental to human civilization. In some cases, we are different from other animals quantitatively (e.g., capacity of memory). In other cases, the ability concerned may be unique to us (e.g., communication with language). It is indeed difficult to imagine a life without these cognitive abilities. In lectures, students will be introduced with the basic concepts and findings about various cognitive abilities including cognition, sensation, perception, memory system, decision-making, and language-processing. In tutorials, they will receive trainings in conducting research in cognitive psychology.

title: Abnormal Psychology
requirements: For students in MA Psychology
description: Dramatic advances have occurred in the past two decades in the study of psychopathology. Human genome has been fully sequenced, the technologies of neuroimaging have made it possible for researchers to observe a brain in action in living people, and psychology has entered the Decade of the Mind. In this new decade, psychology has been re-defined as a science examining how human mind works in general. Abnormal psychology, on the other hand, specializes in understanding how human mind works when it goes haywire. This course is designed to provide you with the most updated knowledge in the field of psychopathology. You will learn about the key concepts of mental disorders, how mental predispositions and upbringing experience interact in the development of various mental disorders, how human mind works in different mental disorders, and more importantly, how you can continue to learn about the science of psychopathology on your own after you have completed the course. After all, learning is about “learning how to learn.”

title: Ethics and Professional Issues
requirements: For students in MSSc Clinical Psychology
description: This course introduces students to the fundamentals of professional and ethical practice as clinical psychologists. References will be made to the most current international perspectives and codes of professional conduct to inform our understanding of best practices as scientist-practitioners. Topics covered in this module include local professional practice guidelines, international codes of conduct, the scientist-practitioner model, evidence-based practices, ethical and legal issues in assessment and research, diversity and multicultural considerations, and professional development issues. This course serves as an orientation to the profession of clinical psychology for new trainees.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should:  1. understand what it means to practice clinical psychology in a professional manner based on codes and standards   established internationally, as well as an understanding for issues specific to professional practice in Hong Kong, 2. be able to apply core ethical principles to clinical practice,  3. be aware of various potential ethical dilemmas and be able to resolve these dilemmas using the appropriate ethical   decision-making strategies,  4. understand the importance of developing and maintaining professional knowledge, skills and competencies, and  5. possess good insight in their ethical obligations as professional clinical psychologists.
syllabus: 1. Codes of Professional Conduct 2. The Scientist-Practitioner Model 3. Empirically Supported Treatments (ESTs) 4. Evidence-based Practices 5. requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology or MPhil-PhD Psychology or PhD Clinical Psychology
description: This course will explore various types of writing as well as techniques to maximize effectiveness in oral presentations essential for psychology for graduate students. Topics to be covered include how to write thesis proposals, grant proposals, empirical studies, manuscript reviews, and review articles. We will also explore techniques for effective critiquing of manuscripts, writing clearly and concisely, understanding and incorporating APA style, and avoiding plagiarism. title: Organizational Placement I
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology
description: Students will be placed to major organizations for internship training for 500 hours. They will work on a specific project in the organization under the joint supervision of a field supervisor of the host organization and a teacher from the Division.
outcome: Upon completion of this practicum, students are expected to:1.  acquire major concepts and theoretical perspectives in IO psychology 2.  apply theoretical perspectives in IO psychology to personal, social, and organizational issues 3.  develop critical thinking skills to make reflection on other values that are the underpinnings of psychology as a discipline 4.  conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during discussions,      on IO psychology-related topics 5.  develop positive values on respecting the complexity of sociocultural diversity develop self-management skills by means      of applying effective strategies for self-improvement attain personal growth through engaging in the practicum with      realistic ideas about how to implement the psychological knowledge, skills, and values in a variety of applied settings
syllabus: 1.  Practicum: Students are expected to work for at least 500 hours at their placement or placements. Usually the longest placements will be during the summer between the first and second year of the MPhil program. Ideally, students should be at their placement for 5 full days per week. Students are advised to work out a detailed schedule with the supervisor at their placement as soon as possible. A copy of the schedule should be given to the instructor for record. In addition to their field supervisor, students will also receive supervision from the instructor.2.  Discussion group: This will be held once a week or every other week during the summer placement. Attendance is mandatory. The purpose of these 2- to 3-hour sessions is to provide students with an opportunity to share their experience working in different settings, observations that they have made, any difficulties they may have encountered, and any issues that may have arisen in their work. These meetings will provide students with a safe environment to learn, seek advice and obtain emotional support.

description: This course covers assessing, interpreting, and communicating individual differences for a variety of work-related purposes including selection and development of skills, abilities, personality, motivation, and interests. Both classical and modern measurement theories and their respective areas of application will be covered.

title: Learning and Development
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology
description: This course provides a critical review of the psychological issues in learning and development. Topics covered include: training needs assessment, psychological principles to enhance training, types of trainings, coaching and mentoring, technology enhanced training, evaluation of training programmes.

title: Seminar in Consumer Psychology
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology
description: This course covers fundamental issues in the psychology of consumer behaviour and advertising. Topics covered include: consumer information processing, consumer decision-making, customer satisfaction, psychology of customer service, attitudes and consumer behaviour, personality and consumer behaviour, social processes in consumer psychology, and psychology of advertising.

title: Seminar in Professional Issues
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology
description: This course will focus on the general professional codes of practice and ethical dilemmas for the practice of industrial-organizational psychology. It also explores the role of industrial-organizational psychologists in general practice, and in team work with other related professionals.

title: Psychopathology
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Psychology or MSSc Clinical Psychology
description: This course introduces students to the key concepts and issues related to various mental disorders. Students will learn about the clinical phenomenology of different mental disorders and how these disorders are classified and diagnosed according to the DSM system. Throughout the course, students will learn to integrate research findings from bio-psycho-social domains and develop an integrative perspective in understanding the development of different mental disorders.
outcome: 1. Understand the key concepts and issues related to various mental disorders 2. Familiarize with the clinical phenomenology of different mental disorders and how these disorders are classified and   diagnosed according to the DSM systems 3. Learn how bio-psycho-social variables interact in the development of various mental disorders 4. Do detailed clinical case analysis according to the integrative bio-psycho-social perspective

title: Health and Community Psychology
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Psychology or MSSc Clinical Psychology
description: This course provides a fundamental background in health and community psychology. Students will have the opportunity to critically examine and evaluate conceptual, methodological, and research issues that are germane in health and community psychology. New developments in these areas will be covered to equip students to lead the field. Focus will be on the synthesis and integration of the two disciplines within a person-in-environment perspective. Students are expected to evaluate issues not only at the individual level, but as well as within the ecology, including groups, settings, communities, cultures, etc. Furthermore, prevention, intervention, and rehabilitation are equally emphasized. It is the aim that students will have a fundamental understanding of major health and community psychology concepts and be able to conceptualize various health issues and formulate sound interventions in an ecological perspective.
outcome: Demonstrate familiarity with the major concepts, theoretical perspectives, empirical findings and recent trends in health and community psychology. Respect and use critical and creative thinking, skeptical inquiry, and scientific approach to understand the dynamics between people’s health behaviors and their communities. Understand how personal, social, societal, and environmental factors contribute to people’s health behaviors. Communicate effectively in a variety of formats and to a variety of audience. Recognize, understand, and respect the complexity of sociocultural diversity and its influence on health behaviors. Emerge from the course with realistic ideas about how to implement their psychological knowledge, skills, and values in public and community health settings.

title: Intelligence Assessment
requirements: For students in MSSc Clinical Psychology
description: This course examines the theoretical, practical and cross-cultural problems in the assessment of intellectual and adaptive functioning. Both the clinical and psychometric approaches will be used. Emphasis will be placed on clinical interview, history-taking and other assessment techniques, test administration, scoring, results interpretation and report writing. A number of the widely used instruments in Hong Kong will be covered, and teaching and learning will take the form of interactive lectures and hands-on experiential learning.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students are expected to: 1. acquire fundamental understanding of major concepts and theories in intelligence and its assessments.  2. be fluent in administering the locally validated intellectual assessment tools (e.g. WISC-IV(HK) and WAIS-IV(HK), as well as adaptive functioning scales.3. acquire basic skills in assessment profile interpretation and report writing as relevant to clinical applications.

title: Assessment of Psychopathology and Personality
requirements: For students in MSSc Clinical Psychology
description: This course focuses on the theoretical, practical and cross-cultural issues related to the assessment of psychopathology and personality. Students will be exposed to a variety of clinical evaluation protocols used for the collection of data in order to evaluate the psycholopathological status of an individual. They will learn about the application of these techniques to a wide range of clinical psychological problems as stipulated in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual for Mental Disorder Version 5 (DSM-V). These include mental state examination, test administration and interpretation, diagnostic decision making, integration of material derived from patient history and other sources, and comprehensive case conceptualization.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should:   1. gain an understanding of how psychopathology is conceptualised and assessed, 2. have a working knowledge of current assessment and evaluation methods in psychopathology, their procedures and   caveats, 3. be informed about some of the adjunct evaluative and diagnostic tools such as the Chinese Minnesota Multiphasic   Personality Inventory-2 (CMMPI-2), the Millon Clinical Multiaxial Inventory-III (MCMI-III), Structured Interview for DSM-IV   (SCID), Composite International Diagnostic Interview (CIDI), Anxiety Disorder Interview Schedule for DSM-IV (ADIS) and   other self-rating and clinician-rated inventories as appropriate, 4. attain competence in clinical interviewing skills augmented by formalized assessment procedures, diagnosis and   differential diagnosis in accordance with the DSM-V, comprehensive case conceptualisation, formulation of   psychopathology and clinical report writing.
syllabus: 1. The clinical examination protocol, 2. A historical perspective of psychopathology and personality with reference to Freud, Adler, Watson, Pavlov, Skinner,   Bandura, Mischel, Rogers, Zuckerman, Sheldon, Cattell, Eysenck, Kelly, Tellegen, Plomin, McCrae and Costa, etc. 3. Personality assessment methods with particular reference to the CMMPI-2, the MCMI-III, SCID, CIDI, ADIS, and other self-  rated and clinician-rated scales, 4. Introduction to psychodiagnosis and differential diagnosis, 5. Integration of information, clinical data and assessment results leading to a clinical formulation of psychopathology, and 6. Assessment-informed intervention planning.

title: Intervention Seminar I: Behavioural and Cognitive Therapies
requirements: For students in MSSc Clinical Psychology
description: The course will serve as the first introduction to behavioural and cognitive therapies and emphasize both theoretical and practical training. It aims at training students basic competence to begin practising behavioural and cognitive therapies for adult psychological/psychiatric disorders. In the first part of the course, the general procedure of behavioural and cognitive therapies will be discussed, while in the second part, the application of behavioural and cognitive therapies to specific disorders, e.g., depression, anxiety disorders, substance-related disorders, personality disorders, and psychotic disorders, etc., will be elaborated. A substantial proportion of time during class will be allocated to discussing simulated therapy sessions on videotapes. The students are expected to do their own readings before coming to class. They will be required to make presentations on the application of behavioural and cognitive therapies to specific disorders, as well as on intervention studies regarding their efficacy and effectiveness.
outcome: Students are expected to develop basic competence to begin practising behavioural and cognitive therapies for adult psychiatric disorders. Upon completion of the course, students should learn the general procedure of behavioural and cognitive therapies and their application to various disorders, e.g., depression, anxiety disorders, personality disorders, substance-related disorders, and psychotic disorders, etc.
syllabus: 1. Overview of behavioural and cognitive therapies 2. Behavioural and cognitive assessment 3. Identification, evaluation and modification of automatic thoughts, intermediate beliefs, and core belief 4. Behavioural experiment, graded exposure, homework 5. Relaxation training, social skills training, problem-solving skills training 6. Termination, and relapse prevention 7. Behaviour therapy/modification 8. Application to different disorders, e.g., depression, anxiety disorders, personality disorders, substance-related disorders,   psychotic disorders, etc. 9. Theoretical integrative overview, & other new developments
